repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Neovim QT was originally bundled on Windows as a response to the then
lackluster terminal options. The situation has dramatically changed,
with viable options such as Windows terminal, Alacritty and Wezterm to
name a few. The Windows build no longer needs this special treatment for
neovim to be usable.

Pros:
  - Release builds will be smaller.
  - Less maintenance burden.
  - Clearer separation of responsibility (neovim issues go to the neovim
    repo and neovim-qt issues to the neovim-qt repo).
  - More consistent treatment between platforms.

Cons:
  - Users who've come to expect neovim-qt to be bundled with nvim will
    need to adjust and download neovim-qt from
    https://github.com/equalsraf/neovim-qt instead.
  - Similarly, build scripts will need to be adjusted to reflect this
    change.

Closes https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/21209.

comment_data.body:
I don't think this needs a news entry; this is more a project-level change that doesn't affect users _already having Neovim_.

Marking this as breaking is enough to put it front and center in the release notes.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -81,6 +81,8 @@ The following deprecated functions or APIs were removed.
 • Vimball support is removed.
   - :Vimuntar command removed.
 
+• Neovim QT is no longer shipped.

comment_regular_data.body: Pinging @equalsraf for comments and awareness as they're responsible for nvim qt as I understand it.

I recall that it was discussed earlier in the year. If there was a conclusion from that discussion (cost/benefit analysis) it should be included in the commit message / description here.

- pro:
    - the release archive will be much smaller.
    - Windows users now have winget and scoop, so installing nvim-qt is easy.
- con:
    -  I don't perceive a big maintenance burden here, but corrections welcome.
Maintenance burden includes regular issues on this repo about neovim-qt problems, which wastes time for both maintainers and users (getting the run-around).

> I don't perceive a big maintenance burden here

Doesn't this assume the feature itself is required to begin with? I don't know why it's a con for us nor users to state "download neovim-qt from equalsraf/neovim-qt instead of neovim/neovim". The end product should still be the same at the end of the day.

The previous discussion on this is [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/21866). I can't see any cost/benefit analysis there. @justinmk's [comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/21866#issuecomment-1400109363) is the closest thing to a conclusion I can see, but I don't know what "Once we have better messaging and discovery of available GUIs on [neovim.io](https://neovim.io/) , then we could consider dropping nvim-qt in our releases." means in practice.

I'm unsure how to make progress on this or what I need to do to unblock it.

That sounds like a statement made before TUI got generally usable on windows.

The generally discoverable GUI on windows is now the TUI, just like on POSIX plattforms. So I would say we have reached that condition.

Several Neovim GUIs are available from scoop (extras): https://scoop.sh/#/apps?q=neovim

So maybe just add a line at the end of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/wiki/Installing-Neovim#scoop to that effect?

> So maybe just add a line at the end of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/wiki/Installing-Neovim#scoop to that effect?

If that'll help move this PR forward then sure, although I don't personally understand the reasoning. The premise of this PR is that Windows is now a big boy OS with features like terminals and package managers, and no longer needs special treatment.

Edit: added it to wiki.

> Pinging @equalsraf for comments and awareness as they're responsible for nvim qt as I understand it.

Thanks for the ping lads. I happily endorse whatever you consider is best here.

> That sounds like a statement made before TUI got generally usable on windows.

This, I think is the only aspect that matters. If the TUI is working well on windows then task complete.

It is probably worth putting some instructions in the wiki on how to start nvim.exe in the windows terminal, or other similar tidbits. But I'm sure those will emerge in time.

@equalsraf glad to hear :)

Do you need to make any preparations before we pull the plug on nvim-qt? I'm ready to accommodate and help this process in any way I can.

> Do you need to make any preparations before we pull the plug on nvim-qt? I'm ready to accommodate and help this process in any way I can.

We are good on my end. As far as I can see there is also a neovim-qt pkg in scoop.
@justinmk I'm probably biased, but I can't come up with any real cons for this.

The con is mostly inertia / user expectations + "sunk cost" in terms of build scripting. But we have a path forward for discovering GUIs (website, maybe more TBD), and the Windows-only nature of this current approach is not good. So we should move forward.
